Data Source: URS Corporation


           56th Avenue                                                          FIGURE 6  2
   Traffic and Safety Report                                                    Quebec Street to Havana Street Alternative 3: Roadway and Intersection Geometry
Quebec Street to Peña Boulevard
                                           56th Avenue Corridor ­ Quebec Street to Peña Boulevard
                                                                         Traffic and Safety Report



The operational deficiencies at 56th Avenue/Quebec Street are primarily results of vehicles
navigating around the Rocky Mountain Arsenal National Wildlife Refuge. The southbound left
turn in particular requires a large amount of green time to serve the demand for that
movement. No other reasonable intersection improvements were found that enabled the
intersection to operate at LOS D or better.

Summary of Traffic Operations
Traffic patterns along the corridor show that with the additional through lanes, the demand
along the entire length of the corridor increases, especially from Valentia Street to Peoria
Street. The directional splits indicate a commuting pattern using the entire length of the
corridor that is westbound in the AM peak hour and eastbound in the PM peak hour.

Improvements were assumed at four of the study intersections to enhance intersection
operations within the corridor to acceptable levels (LOS D or better). Even with
improvements, operational analysis for the Alternative 3 section indicated deficiencies at one
intersection: 56th Avenue/Quebec Street. Besides the improvements assumed for the
intersection, no other reasonable improvements could be determined at Quebec Street that
would raise the level of service to an acceptable level (LOS D).

6.5 Alternative 5: Widen 56th Avenue to Six Lanes from
    Valentia Street to Havana Street ­
    Analysis of 2035 Traffic Conditions
Introduction
Alternative 5: Widen 56th Avenue to Six Lanes from Valentia Street to Havana Street included
five lanes from Quebec Street to Valentia Street and six lanes from Valentia Street to Havana
Street. The surrounding roadway network remained the same as determined in the No-Action
Alternative. It is anticipated that the 2035 traffic volumes on Spruce Street and Dallas Street
will warrant traffic signals under these conditions and traffic signals may be installed at these
locations as a result. These signals are located at approximate ¼- to ½-mile intervals, which
were determined to be acceptable spacing for adequate traffic progression.

Network Assumptions
The following improvements were assumed to study intersections to provide operations at LOS
D or better. Reasonable improvements were included for intersections where LOS D was not
achievable.

·   Quebec Street: Added a southbound right turn lane.
·   Spruce Street: Installed a traffic signal.
·   Central Park Boulevard: Added a westbound right turn lane, an eastbound right turn lane,
    a second northbound left turn lane, and a second westbound left turn lane.
·   Dallas Street: Installed a traffic signal.



                                                 6-9
                                                   56th Avenue Corridor ­ Quebec Street to Peña Boulevard
                                                                                 Traffic and Safety Report



Alternative 5 peak hour traffic volumes are shown in Figure 6-3. The number of roadway
lanes and intersection geometry are shown in Figure 6-4.

Results of Travel Patterns Analysis
The highest travel demand along 56th Avenue continues to be forecast between Quebec Street
and Valentia Street under Alternative 5. The additional through lanes provide for more
demand to be forecast through the eastern portion of the section that is demonstrated by the
increased demand from Valentia Street to Peoria Street.

Intersection Level of Service

The intersection Level of Service results are shown in Table 6.5-1.

                                                Table 6.5-1
                              Alternative 5: Quebec Street to Havana Street

Under Alternative 5, one of the signalized intersections is forecast to operate at undesirable
levels (LOS E or poorer) during at least one peak hour.

The 56th Avenue/Quebec Street intersection is forecast to operate at level of service E (LOS
E) during both peak hours.       During the AM peak hour, the eastbound, northbound, and
southbound approaches are forecast to be near capacity (LOS E). The southbound and
eastbound approaches are forecast to be over capacity (LOS F) and the northbound approach
is forecast to be near capacity (LOS E) during the PM peak hour.

           56th Avenue                                                          FIGURE 6  4
   Traffic and Safety Report                                                    Quebec Street to Havana Street Alternative 5: Roadway and Intersection Geometry
Quebec Street to Peña Boulevard
                                          56th Avenue Corridor ­ Quebec Street to Peña Boulevard
                                                                        Traffic and Safety Report



The operational deficiencies at 56th Avenue/Quebec Street are primarily results of vehicles
navigating around the Rocky Mountain Arsenal National Wildlife Refuge. The southbound left
turn in particular requires a large amount of green time to serve the demand for that
movement. No other reasonable intersection improvements were found that enabled the
intersection to operate at LOS D or better.

Summary of Traffic Operations
Traffic patterns along the corridor show that with the additional through lanes, the demand
along the entire length of the corridor increases, especially from Valentia Street to Peoria
Street. The directional splits indicate a commuting pattern using the entire length of the
corridor that is westbound in the AM peak hour and eastbound in the PM peak hour.

Improvements were assumed at four of the study intersections to enhance intersection
operations within the corridor to acceptable levels (LOS D or better).        Even with
improvements, operational analysis for Alternative 5 indicated deficiencies at one
intersection: 56th Avenue/Quebec Street.        Besides the improvement assumed for the
intersection, no other reasonable improvements could be determined at Quebec Street that
would raise the level of service to an acceptable level (LOS D).

6.6 Alternative 7: Widen 56th Avenue to
    Six Lanes from Quebec Street to Havana Street -
    Analysis of 2035 Traffic Conditions
Introduction
Alternative 7: Widen 56th Avenue to Six Lanes from Quebec Street to Havana Street examined
forecast traffic conditions with six lanes from Quebec Street to Havana Street. The portion of
56th Avenue east of Havana Street remained in the existing condition. The surrounding
roadway network remained the same as determined in the No-Action Alternative. It is
anticipated that the 2035 traffic volumes on Spruce Street and Dallas Street will warrant
traffic signals under these conditions and traffic signals may be installed at these locations as
a result. These signals are located at approximate ¼ to ½ mile intervals, which were
determined to be acceptable spacing for adequate traffic progression.

Network Assumptions
The following improvements were assumed to study intersections along the improved sections
of the corridor to provide operations at LOS D or better. Reasonable improvements were
included for intersections where LOS D was not achievable.

·   Quebec Street: Added a southbound right turn lane.
·   Spruce Street: Installed a traffic signal.
·   Central Park Boulevard: Added an eastbound right turn lane, a westbound right turn lane
    and a second northbound right turn lane.



                                                 6-13
                                                   56th Avenue Corridor ­ Quebec Street to Peña Boulevard
                                                                                 Traffic and Safety Report



Alternative 7 peak-hour traffic volumes are shown in Figure 6-5. The number of roadway
lanes and intersection geometry are shown in Figure 6-6.

Results of Travel Patterns Analysis
The highest travel demand is forecast in the western portion of the corridor between Quebec
Street and Valentia Street under Alternative 7. The additional through lanes to Havana Street
provide for more demand to be forecast through the corridor to Peoria Street, but projected
volumes continue to show a large number of vehicles accessing the corridor at Central Park
Boulevard and Havana Street.

Intersection Level of Service
The Level of Service results for Alternative 7 are shown in Table 6.6-1.

Under Alternative 7 conditions in 2035, one of the signalized intersections is forecast to
operate at undesirable levels (LOS E or poorer) during at least one peak hour.

The 56th Avenue/Quebec Street intersection is forecast to operate at LOS E during the AM
peak hour and LOS F during the PM peak hour. During the AM peak hour, the eastbound,
northbound, and southbound approaches are forecast to be near capacity (LOS E). The
southbound, northbound, and eastbound approaches are forecast to be over capacity (LOS F)
during the PM peak hour.

           56th Avenue                                                          FIGURE 6  6
   Traffic and Safety Report                                                    Quebec Street to Havana Street Alternative 7: Roadway and Intersection Geometry
Quebec Street to Peña Boulevard
                                                   56th Avenue Corridor ­ Quebec Street to Peña Boulevard
                                                                                 Traffic and Safety Report



The operational deficiencies at 56th Avenue/Quebec Street are primarily results of vehicles
trying to navigate around the Rocky Mountain Arsenal National Wildlife Refuge. The
southbound left turn in particular requires a large amount of green time to serve the demand
for that movement. No other reasonable intersection improvements were found that enabled
the intersection to operate at LOS D or better.

Summary of Traffic Operations
Traffic patterns along the corridor show that with the additional through lanes, the demand
along the entire length of the corridor increases, especially from Valentia Street to Peoria
Street. The directional splits indicate a commuting pattern using the entire length of the
corridor that is westbound in the AM peak hour and eastbound in the PM peak hour.

At three of the study intersections, improvements were assumed to enhance intersection
operations within the corridor to acceptable levels (LOS D or better).       Even with
improvements, operational analysis for the Alternative 7 indicated deficiencies at one
intersection: 56th Avenue/Quebec Street. Besides the improvement assumed for the
intersection, no other reasonable improvements could be determined at Quebec Street that
would raise the level of service to an acceptable level (LOS D).

6.7 Summary of Quebec Street to Havana Street
    Alternatives
Intersection Level of Service
The intersection level of service results during the AM peak hour (Table 6.7-1) show that
most intersections are forecast to operate at acceptable levels of service (LOS D or better)
under all of the Alternatives.

No-Action: Three of the intersections are forecast to operate at LOS E or F. Two of the
intersections, Spruce Street and Dallas Street were assumed to be unsignalized and had stop-
controlled approaches that operate at LOS F. The intersection at Quebec Street is forecast to
operate at LOS E. The level of service results show that No-Action conditions will not
adequately serve the demand forecast for 2035 at most intersections.

Alternative 3: Widen to Four Lanes from Valentia Street to Havana Street conditions forecast
one intersection to operate at LOS E or F. Quebec Street is forecast to operate at LOS E. The
level of service results show that demand forecast for 2035 is adequately served by most of
the intersections in the corridor. At Quebec Street, the critical movements are forecast to be
over capacity, causing the degraded levels of service.

Alternative 5: Widen to Six Lanes from Valentia Street to Havana Street conditions forecast
one intersection operating at LOS E or F. Quebec Street is expected to operate at LOS E
because the westbound approach is forecast to be over capacity. The remainder of the
intersections in the corridor is expected to operate at acceptable levels and serve the
demand forecast for the year 2035.

Alternative 7: Widen to Six Lanes from Quebec Street to Havana Street conditions forecast
one intersection operating at LOS E or F. Quebec Street is expected to operate at LOS E since
the westbound approach is forecast to be over capacity. The remainder of the intersections
in the corridor is expected to operate at acceptable levels and serve the demand forecast for
the year 2035.

The intersection level of service results during the PM peak hour (Table 6.7-2) show that
most intersections are expected to operate at acceptable levels of service (LOS D or better)
under most of the Alternatives.

No-Action: Four of the intersections operate at LOS E or F. Two of the intersections, Spruce
Street and Dallas Street were assumed to be unsignalized and had stop-controlled approaches
that operate at LOS F. The intersections at Central Park Boulevard and Havana Street are
forecast to operate at LOS E. The level of service results show that No-Action conditions will
not adequately serve the demand forecast for 2035 at most intersections.

Alternative 3: Widen to Four Lanes from Valentia Street to Havana Street conditions forecast
one intersection to operate at LOS E or F. Quebec Street is forecast to operate at LOS E. The
level of service results show that the demand forecast for 2035 is adequately served by most
of the intersections in the corridor. At the Quebec Street, the critical movements are forecast
to be over capacity, causing the degraded levels of service.

Alternative 5: Widen to Six Lanes from Valentia Street to Havana Street conditions forecast
one intersection operating at LOS E or F. Quebec Street is expected to operate at LOS E since
the westbound approach is forecast to be over capacity. The remainder of the intersections
in the corridor is expected to operate at acceptable levels and serve the demand forecast for
the year 2035.

Alternative 7: Widen to Six Lanes from Quebec Street to Havana Street conditions forecast
one intersection operating at LOS E or F. Quebec Street is expected to operate at LOS F since
several approaches are forecast to be over capacity. The remainder of the intersections in
the corridor is expected to operate at acceptable levels and serve the demand forecast for
the year 2035.

Reasonable improvements were made to the 56th Avenue/Quebec Street intersection to allow
it to operate as well as possible given the traffic demands. Under all the aforementioned
alternatives excluding No-Action and Alternative 2, this intersection consists of dual left-turn
lanes, three through lanes and one right-turn lane on the northbound and southbound
approaches, respectively; and dual left-turn lanes, dual through lanes and one right-turn lane
on the eastbound and southbound approaches respectively. Due to right-of-way restrictions, it
was determined that no further improvements can be made to increase the intersection LOS
to "D" or better for the design year 2035.




                                             6-19
This page is intentionally left blank.
                                         56th Avenue Corridor ­ Quebec Street to Peña Boulevard
                                                                       Traffic and Safety Report



7.0 HAVANA STREET TO PEÑA BOULEVARD
    (CORRIDOR STUDY SECTION)
    PRELIMINARY BUILD ALTERNATIVES
7.1 Definition of Alternatives
URS developed seven different build alternatives for the Havana Street to Peña Boulevard
section of 56th Avenue. Each alternative for this section of 56th assumes a six-lane section from
Quebec Street to Havana Street. All of these alternatives offer various levels of improvement
and are identified as follows:

·   Alternative 1: No Action.
·   Alternative 2: Transportation System Management (TSM)  limited improvements to
    intersections and no improvements to roadway capacity.
·   Alternative 3: Improve parallel roads.
·   Alternative 4: Construct new parallel road.
·   Alternative 5: Widen the section from Havana Street to Peña Boulevard to four lanes.
·   Alternative 6: The same improvements as Alternative 5 with the addition of on-street
    bicycle lanes from Havana Street to Peña Boulevard.
·   Alternative 7: Widen the section from Havana Street to Peña Boulevard to six lanes.
·   Alternative 8: The same improvements as Alternative 7 with the addition of on-street
    bicycle lanes from Havana Street to Peña Boulevard.

Table 7.1-1 summarizes the proposed improvements for each section of 56th Avenue under
each alternative.




                                               7-1
                                                   56th Avenue Corridor ­ Quebec Street to Peña Boulevard
                                                                                 Traffic and Safety Report



                                               Table 7.1-1
                         Havana Street to Peña Boulevard (Corridor Study section)
                                        Description of Alternatives
                                      Havana Street to
  Alternative                         Peña Boulevard                                     Other
       1                                 No-Action                                     No-Action
       2                    Limited improvements to intersections                         None
                                                                                        Improve
        3
                                               None                                  parallel roads
        4                                                                      Construct new parallel road
        5                               Widen to 4 lanes

                                        Widen to 6 lanes
        8                                plus on-street
                                         bicycle lanes
Source: URS Corporation from the 2035 DRCOG regional transportation model




7.2 Fatal Flaw Screening of Alternatives
A fatal flaw screening process was used to eliminate all non-viable alternatives prior to more
detailed investigations and screening. The following set of evaluation criteria was established
for the initial screening phase to assess the full range of alternatives developed for the 56th
Avenue improvements:

1. Project goals and issues. Alternatives that did not satisfy the project vision, meet goals
    or address issues that were established for this project were eliminated as a result of the
    initial screening, and therefore excluded from further consideration.

2. Environmental impacts. The potential impacts of transportation alternatives on
    environmental resources present in the project area were analyzed. An alternative was
    eliminated during the initial screening if it was found to have major negative impacts on
    environmental resources and these impacts would be difficult to avoid or mitigate.

3. Practicality and feasibility. Various factors, such as extraordinary cost, extreme
    complexity of implementation, outstanding constructability issues, and right-of-way
    limitations, could render an alternative to be impractical or not feasible during the initial
    screening. Alternatives considered as impractical or unfeasible were eliminated.

Alternative 2, which considered limited improvement at intersections and no improvements to
roadway capacity, did not meet the study's project goals and issues and was eliminated
during the initial "fatal flaw" screening process. Similarly, Alternatives 3 and 4 that


                                                           7-2
                                                   56th Avenue Corridor ­ Quebec Street to Peña Boulevard
                                                                                 Traffic and Safety Report



considered only "off corridor" improvements also did not meet the study's project goals and
issues and were eliminated during the initial "fatal flaw" screening process.

7.3 Comparison of General Traffic Characteristics
All of the Proposed Action Alternatives were analyzed using the same principles and
methodologies from the previous analyses as described in Section 3.0, for the AM and PM peak
hours.

On-street bicycle lanes have a very limited effect on traffic operations, therefore, only
Alternatives 5 and 7 were analyzed in detail. Alternatives 6 and 8 were assumed to have the
same traffic operations as the corresponding alternative without bicycle lanes.

Average Daily Traffic
The summary of average daily traffic forecasts for each Corridor Study alternative presented
in Table 7.3-1 shows that Alternative 7 averaged the highest forecast daily traffic along the
length of the corridor. No-Action conditions averaged the lowest forecast daily traffic. As the
capacity along the corridor is increased, regional mobility improved, allowing more traffic to
use the corridor on a daily basis.

                                               Table 7.3-1
                         Havana Street to Peña Boulevard (Corridor Study section)

Corridor Study Affect of Parallel Corridors
During the analysis process, it was noted that as capacity was added to 56th Avenue,
additional traffic began to use the facility. This condition begged the question, if 56th Avenue
is not expanded, where does all the traffic that cannot be served go? The DRCOG travel
demand model was used to quantify the volume changes on parallel corridors, as capacity was


                                                           7-3
                                                    56th Avenue Corridor ­ Quebec Street to Peña Boulevard
                                                                                  Traffic and Safety Report



restricted on 56th Avenue. The change in daily volume was averaged over three screen lines
at Havana Street, Peoria Street and Chambers Road. Table 7.3-2 presents the average daily
amount of diverted traffic on select parallel roadways as well as the total amount of traffic
diverted from 56th Avenue itself. During the analysis process it was noted that 104th Avenue
did not serve much (<1%) of the diverted traffic from 56th Avenue, therefore it was not
included in the table.

                                           Table 7.3-2
                     Havana Street to Peña Boulevard (Corridor Study section)
                        Diverted Daily Volumes to Parallel Facilities (2035)
                                        Alternative                 Change in Daily Traffic Forecast (2035)
                                        7: Widen to
                                         Six Lanes                                      Alternative 5: Widen to Four
                                                          Alternative 1: No-Action
                                       from Havana                                      Lanes from Havana to Peña
                                          to Peña
                                            Daily        Diverted                        Diverted
                                                                       % of Diversion                % of Diversion
Parallel Corridor                        Forecast         Trips                           Trips
E-470                                      31,900           650             3%              50                1%
         th
East 120 Avenue                           30,800            310             1%             120                2%
        th
East 96 Avenue                            30,300            880             4%             210                3%
East 56th Avenue                          42,900          -21,300      (-50% served)      -6,200      (-15% served)

I-70                                      270,000          3,280            15%            510                8%
Colfax Avenue                             40,500            360             2%             200                3%
Source: URS Corporation from the 2035 DRCOG regional transportation model

The analysis shows that fifteen percent of drivers that would prefer to use 56th Avenue use an
alternate route when only four lanes are provided between Havana Street and Peña
Boulevard. When only two lanes are provided over this same stretch, fifty percent of drivers
use an alternate route. The highest proportion of the diverted traffic uses I-70 as its
alternate route under both conditions. The diversion of traffic onto parallel facilities under
the two- and four-lane alternatives will likely result with higher traffic volumes through the
Montbello neighborhood and surrounding residential areas.

Average Travel Times and Roadway Congestion
Additional operational parameters were calculated for each Corridor Study alternative.
Average travel speed forecasts were calculated to demonstrate the ability of the proposed
improvements to increase the mobility along the corridor. Roadway congestion values were
calculated to demonstrate how the improvements will meet the forecast demand in 2035.

Average travel speed was calculated using the Synchro analysis networks developed for each
alternative. Average approach delays at each intersection and average link travel times were
used to develop average travel speeds in the peak direction for each peak hour. These
speeds were then combined into one overall average travel speed. The average travel speed
forecasts for each alternative are shown in Table 7.3-3.




                                                           7-4
                                                   56th Avenue Corridor ­ Quebec Street to Peña Boulevard
                                                                                 Traffic and Safety Report

                     Havana Street to Peña Boulevard (Corridor Study section)

Alternative 5: Widen to Four Lanes from
                                                        28.9 mph              25.5 mph       27.4 mph
Havana to Peña

                                                        27.9 mph              29.6 mph       28.7 mph
Havana to Peña
Source: URS Corporation from the 2035 DRCOG regional transportation model



Alternative 7 forecasts the highest average travel speed during both peak hours. No-Action
conditions forecast the lowest average travel speed. In general, the results show higher
travel speeds for alternatives with wider roadway sections.

Roadway congestion was represented by link-based volume to capacity (v/c) ratios. Link
capacities were derived from the signal timings along the corridor in the Synchro analysis
networks for each alternative. A weighted overall v/c was calculated for the peak direction
during each peak hour based on the length of each analysis section. An overall v/c for both
peak hours combined was also calculated. The forecast v/c values for each alternative are
shown in Table 7.3-4.

                                                Table 7.3-4
                         Havana Street to Peña Boulevard (Corridor Study section)

Havana to Peña

* Over capacity conditions are shown in BOLD.

The results show that both Alternative 5 and Alternative 7 are forecast to operate at capacity
(0.9<v/c<1.0). No-Action conditions are forecast to be over capacity (v/c>1.0).

7.4 Corridor Study Alternative 5: Widen 56th Avenue to
    Four Lanes from Havana Street to Peña Boulevard ­
    Analysis of 2035 Traffic Conditions
Introduction
The Corridor Study Alternative 5: Widen 56th Avenue to Four Lanes from Havana Street to
Peña Boulevard roadway network included a four lane roadway section on 56th Avenue from
Havana Street to Peña Boulevard.

It is anticipated that the 2035 traffic volumes on Uvalda Street and Crown Boulevard will
warrant traffic signals under these conditions and traffic signals may be installed at these
locations as a result. These signals are located at approximate ½ to 1 mile intervals, which
are acceptable spacing for adequate traffic progression and provision for reasonable
signalized access to 56th Avenue.

Network Assumptions
The following improvements were assumed to study intersections to provide operations at LOS
D or better. Reasonable improvements were included for intersections where LOS D was not
achievable.

·   Havana Street: Added a second westbound left turn lane. Converted the westbound right
    turn lane into a shared through/right lane.
·   Peoria Street: Added a second westbound left turn lane.
·   Uvalda Street: Installed a traffic signal.
·   Crown Boulevard: Installed a traffic signal.

The Alternative 5 peak-hour traffic volumes are shown in Figure 7-1. The geometry and
control at each intersection is shown in Figure 7-2.

                                                                                                                                                    TOWER RD.
                                                   56th Avenue Corridor ­ Quebec Street to Peña Boulevard
                                                                                 Traffic and Safety Report



Results of Travel Patterns Analysis
The highest travel demand is forecast in the western portion of the Corridor Study between
Havana Street and Peoria Street under Alternative 5. The additional through lanes allow
more demand to be forecast through the eastern portion of the section that is demonstrated
by the increased demand from Peoria Street to Peña Boulevard.

During the AM peak hour, an average of 2,800 vehicles is forecast in the westbound (peak)
direction. The alternative serves approximately 2,700 vehicles in the eastbound direction
during the PM peak hour.

Intersection Level of Service

The intersection level of service results are shown in Table 7.4-1.

                                                Table 7.4-1
                      Corridor Study Alternative 5: Havana Street to Peña Boulevard
                                 Signalized Intersection Level of Service

                                                                                  Level of Service
  Intersection of 56th Avenue and:                                           AM                      PM
  Havana Street                                                               B                       F
  Peoria Street                                                               B                      E
  Uvalda Street                                                               D                      D
  Crown Boulevard                                                             C                      B
  Chambers Road                                                               C                      B
  Airport Way                                                                 A                      A
  Peña Boulevard Southbound ramps                                             D                      C
  Peña Boulevard Northbound ramps                                             B                      D
Source: URS Corporation from the 2035 DRCOG regional transportation model
* Undesirable operations (LOS E or poorer) are shown in BOLD.


                            Signalized Intersection                   Average delay
                               Level of Service                         (sec/veh)
                                       A                                   < 10
                                       B                               >10 and <20
                                      C                                >20 and <35
                                      D                                >35 and <55
                                       E                               >55 and <80
                                       F                                   >80
                       Source: Highway Capacity Manual, 2000




Under Alternative 5, two of the signalized intersections are forecast to operate at undesirable
levels (LOS E or poorer) during at least one peak hour.




                                                           7-9
                                         56th Avenue Corridor ­ Quebec Street to Peña Boulevard
                                                                       Traffic and Safety Report



·   The 56th Avenue/Havana Street intersection is forecast to operate at level of service
    (LOS) F during the PM peak hour. During this period, the eastbound approach is forecast
    to be over capacity (LOS F). This is the location where the roadway transitions from
    three eastbound lanes to two eastbound lanes.
·   The 56th Avenue/Peoria Street intersection is forecast to operate at LOS E during the PM
    peak hour. During this period, the eastbound approach is forecast to be over capacity
    (LOS F).
·   The operational deficiencies at Havana Street and Peoria Street are primarily results of
    vehicles traversing 56th Avenue in the eastbound direction. The eastbound through
    demands are higher than the capacity provided by two through lanes. The reduction in
    the number of eastbound lanes from three to two creates a bottleneck which does not
    allow the entire three lane demand to traverse the corridor in the eastbound direction.
    The effect of this bottleneck is demonstrated in the levels of service at Havana Street and
    Peoria Street.

Summary of Traffic Operations
Traffic patterns along the corridor show that with the additional through lanes, the demand
along the entire length of the corridor increases, especially from Peoria Street to Peña
Boulevard. The directional splits indicate a commuting pattern using the entire length of the
corridor that is westbound in the AM peak hour and eastbound in the PM peak hour.

Improvements were assumed at four of the study intersections to enhance intersection
operations within the corridor to acceptable levels (LOS D or better). Even with
improvements, operational analysis under Alternative 5 conditions indicated deficiencies at
two intersections: Havana Street and Peoria Street. These deficiencies are primarily a result
of the bottleneck caused by the reduction in number of through lanes from three to two at
this location within the corridor.

7.5 Corridor Study Alternative 7: Widen 56th Avenue to
    Six Lanes from Havana Street to Peña Boulevard ­
    Analysis of 2035 Traffic Conditions
Introduction
Corridor Study Alternative 7: Widen 56th Avenue to Six Lanes from Havana Street to Peña
Boulevard includes six lanes from Havana Street to Peña Boulevard.

It is anticipated that the 2035 traffic volumes on Uvalda Street and Crown Boulevard will
warrant traffic signals and traffic signals may be installed at these locations as a result. These
signals are located at approximate ½ to 1 mile intervals, which were determined to be
acceptable spacing for adequate traffic progression.




                                              7-10
                                                   56th Avenue Corridor ­ Quebec Street to Peña Boulevard
                                                                                 Traffic and Safety Report



Network Assumptions
The following improvements were assumed to study intersections to provide operations at LOS
D or better. Reasonable improvements were included for intersections where LOS D was not
achievable.

·   Havana Street: Added second westbound left turn lane and converted the northbound
    through lane to a shared through/right lane.
·   Peoria Street: Added northbound right turn lane and second westbound left turn lane.
·   Uvalda Street: Installed traffic signal.
·   Crown Boulevard: Installed traffic signal.
·   Chambers Road: Added third northbound left turn lane.

The Alternative 7 peak-hour traffic volumes are shown in Figure 7-3. The number of roadway
lanes and intersection geometry are shown in Figure 7-4.

Results of Travel Patterns Analysis
The highest travel demand is forecast in the western portion of the Corridor Study section
under Alternative 7. The additional through lanes provide for more demand to be forecast
through the eastern portion of the section which is demonstrated by the increased demand
from Peoria Street to Peña Boulevard.

During the AM peak hour, an average of 4,100 vehicles is forecast in the westbound (peak)
direction. The alternative serves approximately 3,700 vehicles in the eastbound direction
during the PM peak hour.

Intersection Level of Service

The intersection Level of Service results are shown in Table 7.5-1.

                                                Table 7.5-1
                      Corridor Study Alternative 7: Havana Street to Peña Boulevard
                                 Signalized Intersection Level of Service

                                                                                  Level of Service
Intersection of 56th Avenue and:                                                AM              PM
Havana Street                                                                    B               E
Peoria Street                                                                    B               D
Uvalda Street                                                                    D               C
Crown Boulevard                                                                  D               B
Chambers Road                                                                    C               B
Airport Way                                                                      B               A

                                 E                           >55 and <80
                                 F                               >80
                  Source: Highway Capacity Manual, 2000

Under Alternative 7 conditions in 2035, one of the signalized intersections is forecast to
operate at undesirable levels (LOS E or poorer) during at least one peak hour.

·   The 56th Avenue/Havana Street intersection is forecast to operate at LOS E during the PM
    peak hour. During that period, the northbound, southbound, and eastbound approaches
    are forecast to be over capacity (LOS F).
·   The operational deficiencies at Havana Street are primarily results of vehicles traversing
    56th Avenue in the eastbound direction. The eastbound through vehicle demands are
    higher than the capacity provided by three through lanes. This results from the green time
    required to serve both the westbound left turn movement and the northbound
    movements, which limits the green time for eastbound/westbound movements.

Summary of Traffic Operations
Traffic patterns along the corridor show that with the additional through lanes, the demand
along the entire length of the corridor increases, especially from Peoria Street to Peña
Boulevard. The directional splits indicate a commuting pattern using the entire length of the
corridor that is westbound in the AM peak hour and eastbound in the PM peak hour.

Improvements were assumed at four of the study intersections to enhance intersection
operations within the corridor to acceptable levels (LOS D or better).    Even with
improvements, operational analysis for Alternative 7 indicated deficiencies at one
intersection: Havana Street.

7.6 Summary of Havana Street to Peña Boulevard
    Alternatives
Intersection Level of Service
The intersection level of service results during the AM peak hour (Table 7.6-1) show that
most intersections are forecast to operate at acceptable levels of service (LOS D or better)
under all of the alternatives.

                                                Table 7.6-1
                         Havana Street to Peña Boulevard (Corridor Study section)
                             Alternatives 2035 AM Peak Hour Level of Service
                                                                            Level of Service

                                                                        Alternative 5:
                                                                        Widen to Four          Alternative 7:
                                                  Alternative 1:         Lanes from         Widen to Six Lanes
Intersection of 56th Avenue and:                   No-Action           Havana to Peña      from Havana to Peña
Havana Street                                           D                     B                      B
Peoria Street                                           E                     B                      B
Uvalda Street                                           F                     D                      D
Crown Boulevard                                         D                     C                      D
Chambers Road                                           C                     C                      C
Airport Way                                             B                     A                      B
Peña Boulevard Southbound ramps                         F                     D                      C
Peña Boulevard Northbound ramps                         D                     B                      B
Source: URS Corporation from the 2035 DRCOG regional transportation model
* Undesirable operations (LOS E or poorer) are shown in BOLD.
* Unsignalized intersections are shown in italics

No-Action: Three of the intersections are forecast to operate at LOS E or F. One of the
intersections, Uvalda Street, was assumed to be unsignalized. Uvalda Street had a stop-
controlled approach that operates at LOS F. The intersection at Peoria Street is forecast to
operate at LOS E. The intersection at the Peña Boulevard Southbound ramps is forecast to
operate at LOS F. The level of service results show that No-Action conditions will not
adequately serve the demand forecast for 2035 at several intersections.

Alternative 5 conditions forecast all of the intersections to operate at LOS D or better during
the AM peak hour. The corridor is expected to serve the demand forecast for the year 2035.

Alternative 7 conditions forecast all of the intersections to operate at LOS D or better during
the AM peak hour. The corridor is expected to serve the demand forecast for the year 2035.

The intersection level of service results during the PM peak hour (Table 7.6-2) show that
most intersections are expected to operate at acceptable levels of service (LOS D or better)
under most of the Alternatives.




                                                          7-15
                                                   56th Avenue Corridor ­ Quebec Street to Peña Boulevard
                                                                                 Traffic and Safety Report



                                                Table 7.6-2
                         Havana Street to Peña Boulevard (Corridor Study section)
                             Alternatives 2035 PM Peak Hour Level of Service
                                                                            Level of Service
                                                                             Alternative 5:     Alternative 7:
                                                                             Widen to Four      Widen to Six
                                                        Alternative 1:        Lanes from         Lanes from
Intersection of 56th Avenue and:                         No-Action          Havana to Peña     Havana to Peña
Havana Street                                                 E                    F                  E
Peoria Street                                                  D                   E                 D
Uvalda Street                                                  F                  D                  C
Crown Boulevard                                                F                   B                 B
Chambers Road                                                  B                   B                 B
Airport Way                                                    B                   A                 A
Peña Boulevard Southbound ramps                                E                  C                  D
Peña Boulevard Northbound ramps                                E                  D                  B
Source: URS Corporation from the 2035 DRCOG regional transportation model
* Undesirable operations (LOS E or poorer) are shown in BOLD.
* Unsignalized intersections are shown in italics

No-Action: Five of the intersections operate at LOS E or F. Two of the intersections, Uvalda
Street and Crown Boulevard, were assumed to be unsignalized and had stop-controlled
approaches that operate at LOS F. The intersections at Havana Street, the Peña Boulevard
Southbound ramps and the Peña Boulevard Northbound ramps are forecast to operate at LOS
E. The level of service results show that No-Action conditions will not adequately serve the
demand forecast for 2035 at most intersections.

Alternative 5 conditions forecast two intersections operating at LOS E or F. Havana Street is
expected to operate at LOS F since the eastbound approach is forecast to be over capacity.
Peoria Street is forecast to operate at LOS E since the eastbound approach is forecast to be
over capacity. The remaining intersections in the corridor are expected to operate at
acceptable levels and serve the demand forecast for the year 2035.

Alternative 7 conditions forecast one intersection operating at LOS E or F. Havana Street is
expected to operate at LOS E since the eastbound approach is forecast to be over capacity.
The remaining intersections in the corridor are expected to operate at acceptable levels and
serve the demand forecast for the year 2035.

With the increased demand along 56th Avenue resulting from the additional through lanes, the
eastbound lanes operate poorly during the PM peak hour at Havana Street and Peoria Street.
During the PM peak hour, the signals at Havana Street and Peoria Street must serve both the
northbound movements and the westbound left turn movements in addition to the eastbound
through movement in one cycle; the amount of green time the eastbound movement receives
is reduced. The reduction in green time given to the eastbound through movement reduces
the capacity the corridor can carry in the eastbound direction. This does not occur in the
westbound direction since most intersections along the corridor are three-legged
intersections which do not have a southbound approach requiring green time, or have
southbound approaches with very low volumes.


                                                          7-16
                                         56th Avenue Corridor ­ Quebec Street to Peña Boulevard
                                                                       Traffic and Safety Report



8.0 CONCLUSIONS
It is important to note that the DRCOG model runs for each of the different alternatives
projected operations on 56th Avenue at or near capacity. This is mainly a result of the
constrained assignment conditions discussed in section 3.2. With key additions of auxiliary
(turning lanes) at intersections, each alternative for both the Environmental Assessment and
the Corridor Study was able to carry the modeled 2035 traffic at Level of Service D or better
at most intersections. Even so, "trouble spots" remained in each alternative where traffic
was at or over capacity (Levels of Service E and F) for specific movements within the
intersection.

For the Environmental Assessment section under 2035 No-Action conditions, the two-lane
section of roadway between Valentia Street and Havana Street is not able to serve the
forecast demand. This section of roadway is expected to be over capacity. The unsignalized
intersections along the study section are forecast to operate at LOS F. In addition, the
intersections at Quebec Street, Central Park Boulevard, and Havana Street are forecast to
operate at LOS E or F during at least one peak hour.

Alternative 3: Widen 56th Avenue to Four Lanes from Valentia Street to Havana Street peak
hour traffic is forecast to operate at capacity along the length of the study section. The
intersection with Quebec Street is forecast to operate at LOS E during both peak hours.

Alternative 5: Widen 56th Avenue to Six Lanes from Valentia Street to Havana Street peak
hour traffic is forecast to operate under capacity along the length of the study section. The
intersection at Quebec Street is forecast to operate at LOS E during both peak hours.

Alternative 7: Widen 56th Avenue to Six Lanes from Quebec Street to Havana Street peak
hour traffic is forecast to operate under capacity along the length of the study section. The
intersection at Quebec Street is forecast to operate at LOS E during the AM peak hour and LOS
F during the PM peak hour.

For the Corridor Study section under No-Action conditions, the two-lane section between
Peoria Street and Peña Boulevard is not able to serve the forecast demand. This section of
roadway is expected to be over capacity. The unsignalized intersections along the study
section are forecast to operate at LOS F. In addition, the intersections at Peoria Street, the
Peña Boulevard Southbound ramps, and the Peña Boulevard Northbound ramps are forecast to
operate at LOS E or F during at least one peak hour. The alternative is forecast to serve
approximately 1,300 vehicles in the westbound direction during the AM peak hour and 1,300
vehicles in the eastbound direction during the PM peak hour. In addition, the No-Action
alternative is forecast to serve 50 percent less traffic on a daily basis compared to Alternative
7. This increases the likelihood that traffic volumes in the Montbello and surrounding
neighborhoods will increase as drivers find alternate routes parallel to 56th Avenue.

Alternative 5: Widen 56th Avenue to Four Lanes from Havana Street to Peña Boulevard peak
hour traffic is forecast operate at capacity along the length of the study section. The
intersections at Havana Street and Peoria Street are forecast to operate at LOS E or F during
the PM peak hour. The alternative is forecast to serve approximately 2,800 vehicles in the
westbound direction during the AM peak hour and 2,700 in the eastbound direction during the
PM peak hour. In addition, Alternative 5 is forecast to serve 15 percent less traffic on a daily
basis compared to Alternative 7. This increases the likelihood that traffic volumes in the

                                               8-1
                                        56th Avenue Corridor ­ Quebec Street to Peña Boulevard
                                                                      Traffic and Safety Report


Montbello and surrounding neighborhoods will increase as drivers find alternate routes
parallel to 56th Avenue.

Alternative 7: Widen 56th Avenue to Six Lanes from Havana Street to Peña Boulevard peak
hour traffic is forecast to operate at capacity along the length of the study section. The
intersection of Havana Street is forecast to operate at LOS F during the PM peak hour. The
alternative is forecast to serve approximately 4,100 vehicles in the westbound direction
during the AM peak hour and 3,700 in the eastbound direction during the PM peak hour. In
addition, Alternative 7 is forecast to serve the highest volumes on a daily basis compared to
the other Corridor Study alternatives. This decreases the likelihood that traffic volumes in
the Montbello and surrounding neighborhoods will increase since most drivers are able to use
56th Avenue to traverse the corridor.

56th Avenue itself is forecast to experience high peak hour directional volumes. This
characteristic of the modeled traffic behavior on 56th Avenue is due in large part to the Rocky
Mountain Arsenal National Wildlife Refuge.

The size of the RMANWR severely restricts travel between Quebec Street and Peña Boulevard
from 56th Avenue to 96th Avenue. This creates an excess of demand on both Quebec Street
and 56th Avenue in the peak direction of travel. For all of the alternatives presented here,
these high forecast volumes strain the capacity of the roadway since the predominant portion
of traffic is traveling in only one direction.




                                              8-2
  56th Avenue Corridor ­ Quebec Street to Peña Boulevard
                                Traffic and Safety Report
